title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: In red states, many academic researchers feel fear–and resolve
items.description: State-level mandates prompt changes and small acts of resistance at universities

items.title: Headless bodies hint at why Europe’s first farmers vanished
items.description: Wave of mass brutality accompanied the collapse of the first pan-European culture

items.title: Pigeons sense Earth’s magnetic field in an entirely new way
items.description: Specialized hair cells pick electric currents induced by magnetism

items.title: ‘This is censorship.’ Conference requires abstracts to comply with Trump anti-DEI order
items.description: NASA-funded planetary science institute previously scrubbed hundreds of records from its archive

items.title: Why does biology keep building things out of tiles?
items.description: <cite>Science</cite> talks with two scientists about finding the beauty in nature’s mosaics

items.title: Watch superstretchy bloodworms turn themselves inside out
items.description: The marine worm’s unusually structured proboscis could inspire future soft-bodied robots

items.title: Despite Trump chaos, NSF avoided feared dip in research financing
items.description: Number of new grants fell by 20%, but got larger, as funder braced for potential budget cut

items.title: Black holes may be source of Milky Way’s mysterious high-energy cosmic rays
items.description: Researchers at Tibetan observatory trace gamma ray light back to violent microquasars

items.title: Curious gravitational wave may be hint at primordial black holes—or just noise
items.description: Astronomers approach unusual observation with caution and excitement

items.title: Lab-grown models of human brains are advancing rapidly. Can ethics keep pace?
items.description: Whether neural organoids feel pain or should be placed in animals are among the questions swirling around biology’s hot new technology
